slideshow.caption: Arctic Ice Shrinks to Record Low
slideshow.longDescription: In 2012, the Arctic ice cap shrank to the smallest size ever recorded. If the polar ice caps continue to melt at the present rate, by 2100 there could be no Arctic ice at all during the summer.

slideshow.caption: British Virgin Islands Stripped of Greenery by Hurricane Irma
slideshow.longDescription: Once covered in greenery, the British Virgin Islands were left brown and denuded by Hurricane Irma in 2017. Hurricanes could become more powerful as the climate warms.

slideshow.caption: Bolivia’s Lake Poopó runs dry
slideshow.longDescription: In wet periods, Lake Poopó is Bolivia’s second largest lake, covering 3,000 square km (1,200 square miles). Already shrinking as water was diverted for mining and agriculture, the lake ran completely dry after a major drought in 2016.

slideshow.caption: Melting Ice in Greenland
slideshow.longDescription: In 2016, Greenland’s ice sheet became covered by rivers and lakes (visible in blue) earlier in the summer than in previous years. Formed from melting ice, the liquid water digs deep holes into the ice sheet, allowing the water to drain to the bottom of the ice sheet and into the ocean.

slideshow.caption: Shrinking Glaciers in Switzerland
slideshow.longDescription: The Trift Glacier in Switzerland retreated 1.17 kilometers (0.7 miles) between 2006 and 2017.
slideshow.credit: James Balog and the Extreme Ice Survey

slideshow.caption: Hurricane Harvey Causes Flooding in Houston, Texas
slideshow.longDescription: Hurricane Harvey dumped up to 120 cm (47 inches ) in the area around Houston, Texas. The storm displaced 30,000 people, destroyed 200,000 homes and businesses and caused $126 billion in property damage.  Rare extreme weather events like these could become more frequent as the climate warms.

slideshow.caption: Coral Bleaching in American Samoa
slideshow.longDescription: Vast areas of American Samoa’s coral reefs were damaged during a major global bleaching event in the Pacific Ocean in 2015. Temperature increases of even a few degrees can cripple entire reef systems. During a catastrophic 2016 heat wave, 30 percent of the coral in Australia’s Great Barrier Reef died.
